I think the real insight from today's session isn't about drill-down charts specifically but about the entire home screen workflow. When P-044 tried to integrate drill-down charts into their process, they revealed that their actual goal was three steps beyond what our feature supports. We're solving a sub-problem and users have to manually bridge the gap. This came through really clearly and I want to present it at the next product sync. — see JIRA-2302

Watched the participant try to configure field mapping settings and they nailed it on the first try, which was a pleasant surprise given how much trouble P-047 had with the same task last week. The difference might be that this participant came from a data ingestion area background and already had the right mental model for where field mapping would be. So the design works, but only if you already think in this paradigm.

I think the real insight from today's session isn't about gesture controls specifically but about the entire responsive interface workflow. When P-??? tried to use gesture controls for their daily workflow, they revealed that their actual goal was three steps beyond what our feature supports. We're solving a sub-problem and users have to manually bridge the gap. This came through really clearly and I want to present it at the next product sync.

The participant opened the dashboard area panel and immediately started scanning the left sidebar for dashboard templates. They didn't find it there so they tried the top nav, then the settings gear, then right-clicked to see if there was a context menu. Finally found it nested under an accordion they hadn't expanded. The whole thing took about 3 minutes. They were polite about it but you could tell they were annoyed. I want to compare this with the heatmap data from the last round to see if the click patterns match.
"fix this one thing" - P-024 priority signal

So the participant started confidently in subscription area and seemed to know exactly what they wanted to do, which was set up invoice download. But then they hit this wall where invoice download wasn't where they expected it. They opened the help docs in a new tab and searched for it. The fact that they had to leave the product to figure this out is a red flag. Reminds me of the pattern @James Chen flagged in the last sprint review.

## Pain Point
- Issue: batch import performance degrades significantly with large datasets in import wizard
- Severity: Medium-High — blocks power users
- Frequency: Daily for teams with 10k+ records
- User Impact: Users resort to manual export and external processing to load batch import results at scale
- Suggested Fix: Optimize batch import query performance and add progress indicators
"I always forget where gesture controls lives" — participant spent ~2min navigating before finding it in mobile section

One thing that keeps coming up is the disconnect between how we've organized user admin panel and how users think about their work. They don't think in terms of 'permission groups' as a discrete thing — it's part of a larger job-to-be-done that spans multiple product areas. The fact that they have to compare permission groups data across periods in one place and then go somewhere else to complete the workflow is the core friction, not any single UI element.
"This is the one thing that actually works the way I expect" — P-027 on import scheduling in data ingestion area. Unprompted. Only positive comment in entire session.
"Before this tool it took three days. Now three hours. Still not great, but better." — P-??? on field mapping for explain field mapping to a colleague. Mixed sentiment. Acknowledges progress.

## Pain Point
- Issue: No way to undo after completing find webhook management in the interface in developer portal
- Severity: High — data loss risk
- Frequency: Occasional but high-impact when it occurs
- User Impact: P-029 described losing 2 hours of work due to accidental overwrite in webhook management
- Suggested Fix: Implement undo/version history for webhook management operations @james

Esto es un pain point importante — P-060 needs real-time collaboration on billing history in payment section. Currently their team takes turns and uses a spreadsheet to track who's working on what to avoid conflicts when they share billing history configurations with team. They explicitly compared it to Google Docs and said 'if this worked like that, it would save us hours of coordination.' Given how many teams we're seeing with this pattern, I think collaborative editing should be on the roadmap.

Connecting dots across PART-061's session and two from last week — the trust issue with webhook setup in integrations hub is bigger than I initially thought. Users aren't just confused about where to find it, they actively doubt the output accuracy. Two participants mentioned checking results against external tools before sharing with stakeholders. If we can't address the trust gap, feature improvements won't matter.

There's an easy win here that I want to push for quickly — adding saved presets for drill-down charts in overview page. Four out of six participants in this round asked for this independently. The current experience of reconfiguring everything each time they investigate drill-down charts workarounds is creating daily friction that a relatively simple feature could eliminate. I'll work with @product on a spec and plan to validate the prototype with P-038 and others from this cohort.

- Context: During task 3, participant attempted to set up API key generation
- Behavior: Immediately went to API console section, found API key generation on first try
- Impact: This part of the flow is well-designed and intuitive

The participant asked if we have an API for invoice download because they want to automate the share invoice download configurations with team process in billing page. They're an engineer by background and said their team has already built scripts for other tools and would 'absolutely build automation' if endpoints were available. This aligns with what I'm hearing from enterprise accounts — programmatic access is becoming table stakes.

## Insight
- Pattern: Cross-functional teams use analytics area differently based on role
- Evidence: Engineers onboard team members to pivot tables daily; PMs access pivot tables weekly; execs never
- Root Cause: The interface doesn't adapt to usage patterns or role-based needs
- Implication: Consider role-based default views for analytics area

Esto es un pain point importante — P-102 needs real-time collaboration on Zapier integration in integrations hub. Currently their team takes turns and uses a spreadsheet to track who's working on what to avoid conflicts when they customize Zapier integration to fit their needs. They explicitly compared it to Google Docs and said 'if this worked like that, it would save us hours of coordination.' Every single participant this week has complained about API versioning in developer tools. It's the single most consistent pain point in the entire study. The issue is always the same: they need to complete the API versioning process but the feature requires too much context-switching between screens. One participant had 4 tabs of our product open simultaneously just to complete this one task. We need to consolidate this into a single view.
